comments.text:
Anyone with a sensitivity to loud noise or ptsd can be startled and have an 
anxiety or panic attack from knocks on doors the only reason you don't 
believe it happens is because regardless of the damage it does people 
refuse to admit that doing normal things can be harmful to people. Anyways 
that case was obviously stupid and she didn't have much right to sue those 
girls but their parents should be expected to pay for medical bills (if 
any) the fact that she had medical bills obviously indicates the damage 
that can be done. The whole case sounds like a smear on disabled people 
they aren't "sensitive" or any of that shit they cannot help it and it 
almost always has to do with ptsd and is actually fairly common. No one 
makes fun of war veterans startled by construction noises because they 
resemble war sounds, the same thing applies to everyone else. Just because 
knocking on doors is common doesn't mean it's any less startling they 
weren't anticipating it and they did not put themself in the hospital. 

Not saying you should stop knocking on doors, just be careful and don't 
purposefully knock as hard as you possibly can. And even after taking 
countermeasures to help people with ptsd be sympathetic and offer to help 
if they still have a panic attack.

comments.text:
+Christian Ponicki Ok, now you're just sounding like an anarchist wingnut. 
Who stops government from going to far is the people - hence the existence 
of the Second Amendment. At least that's the idea in theory. Logic tells 
nearly anyone that some kind of government needs to be in place or 
corporations and drug cartels simply run the country complete rather than 
partially as they do now. The inherent problem with trying to control 
things ethically is that ethics vary from person to person. The entire 
reason why we have a free society is to allow for various beliefs without 
discrimination. The only real limitations being the law. How you justify 
government morally is simply looking at societies where it's virtually 
nonexistent - such as pretty much the entirety of South Africa. AIDS 
running amuck, insane levels of violence, no accountability for actions at 
all. As for every leader being a power-hungry monster, how do you figure 
that? Many have been, yes, we can agree on that. But I haven't seen too 
many historians not have high levels of respect for Teddy Roosevelt and 
Reagan. Did they make mistakes and do some things that people didn't like - 
absolutely. Name a leader of literally anything that hasn't made decisions 
you didn't like and I'll be surprised. The system rotting since it was 
conceived is an absurd idea. Considering the fact that it worked pretty 
well for us until about the past 50 years says otherwise. We had top-level 
manufacturing plants, the standard of living for the middle class was 
great, and we generally kept out of world affairs unless we saw problems 
that we knew would later impact us. An entirely free market society would 
have all kinds of payoffs and corruption as well - and you would likely see 
the same exportation of manufacturing and other jobs to China that you see 
now. Because it's still all driven by money. If you have a perfect solution 
to all of this, please, fix these issues in government and prove us all 
wrong. Otherwise, I see no point in continuing this conversation.
comments.author: Paul Lander

comments.text:
+Paul Lander
"I've never seen evidence that the existence of a government - not 
necessarily the one we have, is inherently a bad idea"

Of course there's no evidence against a government that doesn't exist. But 
there's plenty of evidence that government is a horrible idea from regimes 
that *do* exist; just look at how they form and where they come from and 
you'll see that everything in the book has been tried and failed. Also, you 
don't necessarily need evidence to know that something is a bad idea when 
logic tells you so.

"But it basically keeps people and businesses alike from going too far and 
sets boundaries that allow a society to avoid total collapse and give it 
order"

And what keeps government from going too far?

"This is supposed to ensure that power is never given 100% to any one party 
and thus this system of "checks and balances" provides a barrier of safety 
against tyrannical government"

What happens if all branches conspire to overcome these obstacles, as they 
inevitably will? Who stops them?

"What needs to be restored is the integrity and lack of bias in government, 
not necessarily the system itself."

It was never there; every leader we've had from Lincoln to FDR has been a 
lying, power hungry, murderous monster. The system has been rotting since 
it was conceived. This rotting simply accelerated with FDR and the New Deal 
era for various reasons.

     You also haven't addressed the ethical issue of government; how is it 
justified morally? Also, why couldn't the free market simply provide the 
things that government currently does?
comments.author: Christian Ponicki

comments.text:
+Christian Ponicki The thing is, government can work in people's favor as 
well as against them. I've never seen evidence that the existence of a 
government - not necessarily the one we have, is inherently a bad idea. 
What it boils down to is accountability. Accountability for the actions of 
one party that can be detrimental to another. I don't mean in terms of big 
businesses, because intense competition in business is a good thing short 
of corporate espionage. But it basically keeps people and businesses alike 
from going too far and sets boundaries that allow a society to avoid total 
collapse and give it order. Ideally in a free society, you have government 
being split into 3 separate houses as we have here, where they watch one 
another's actions closely and to some degree work against one another. This 
is supposed to ensure that power is never given 100% to any one party and 
thus this system of "checks and balances" provides a barrier of safety 
against tyrannical government. The problem that I see is that in the 300 
years politicians have had to study, alter, and misconstrue the law, 
they're following it to the letter but not the spirit. I think that's why 
you see all the absurdly restrictive laws and strange loophole usages that 
are all over the news today. Politicians have figured out that mudslinging 
and backdoor deals are much easier than bothering going through the proper 
channels. The system we're under definitely needs an overhaul, but I don't 
think it's a complete loss. What needs to be restored is the integrity and 
lack of bias in government, not necessarily the system itself. Which in 
this era where it's perfectly acceptable to become famous for scandals, is 
much easier said than done. Personally, I want to see America grow a 
backbone again and thrive on integrity and hard work as it did in 
generations past. My sincere hope is that people in this country will wise 
up and want something similar.
comments.author: Paul Lander

comments.text:
+Paul Lander "Personally, I have no issue with the idea of having 
government"

I might not personally mind some of the things that government does or 
would do, but that has no bearing on whether or not it's ethical - it's 
not. We also can't ignore the fact that giving any actor in the free market 
a guaranteed income and monopoly will inevitably be disastrous for 
themselves at the least and much worse if it's a monopoly on violence.

"There has to be some law or chaos would ensue"

Rules don't require rulers. Also, I think you'd find that such an attitude 
originates not out of rational concern but out of paranoia which we all 
have drilled into us from cradle to grave. This makes perfect sense as 
well; any entity in the free market - especially one that is inefficient or 
destructive - will try it's damnedest to convince everyone of it's 
importance and government is no exception, hence the pro-government 
indoctrination we all face.
     Regarding your assertion, I've heard the "gang warfare" theory 
regarding absence of government before which states that every horrible 
thing imaginable would vie for power without it and while at face value 
it's scary, it isn't actually true in a society in which government is 
rejected; is there demand for a church in an atheistic society?
comments.author: Christian Ponicki

comments.text:
+Christian Ponicki Personally, I have no issue with the idea of having 
government. There has to be some law or chaos would ensue. I just think the 
government should be kept in check and held to it's own standards rather 
than this large-scale "do as I say, not as I do" mentality that the current 
administration holds.
comments.author: Paul Lander

comments.text:
+Paul Lander It seems to me that New Deal-style nonsense was unfortunately 
the inevitable result of having such a free country; the more wealth a 
nation accumulates through the free market, the more money there is to 
potentially draw from and throw into feel-good progressive policies and the 
longer you go uncorrupted, the more wealth you get, making such policies 
more and more attractive as time goes on. This would explain how the US 
went from being the freest country on earth to having the largest 
government on earth in such a short amount of time.
     The way I see it, from any standpoint - whether it's ethical or 
practical - the only system that would work is a free market without a 
government.
comments.author: Christian Ponicki

comments.text:
+Christian Ponicki Personally I still can't understand why people would 
want to drastically alter a system that worked well at it's peak in this 
country in favor of policies that have been proven not to work time and 
again throughout history. The "but it'll work this time" attitude for 
socialism is the one I can't understand. Capitalism works because greed is 
the motivating factor. People can put whatever spin on it they want, but if 
you working harder than the next guy and doing that work in a smarter way 
gets you farther, that's what's going to make you strive to do better, earn 
more, etc. It's a noble idea to give everyone the same thing and have a 
fair society, but fair isn't exactly motivating when you know that you'll 
never get anywhere. Which is the entire reason countries like Russia fell 
apart back in the day. That's my take on the whole thing.
comments.author: Paul Lander

comments.text:
+Paul Lander You hit the nail on the head, and I agree with you regarding 
blame; much of the blame lies with the politicians for introducing such 
disastrous policies in the first place but for some of it, we (some of us) 
can only blame ourselves for supporting it.
comments.author: Christian Ponicki

comments.text:
+Christian Ponicki My dad was a history teacher for over 30 years and he 
taught me most of what he knew, so believe me, I'm more than familiar with 
the evils of socialism and how twisted the current European political model 
is. Nobody is more against that stuff than me. Admittedly, my choice of 
words in my initial statement was not the best. In recognition of this, 
I'll amend it - Most Americans that I was raised around and know in my 
current life today are hardworking, sensible people. However, I do know a 
great deal more people than I would care to admit in this country that have 
little sense of any kind, and those are the individuals that have created 
the "American's are retarded" attitude. We can most certainly agree that 
most of the problems we are seeing in modern society here are caused by 
European socialist/fascist ideals being brought over. Gun ban policies, 
socialized healthcare, poor quality of education, just to name a few. But I 
definitely think that we have some issues that we only have ourselves to 
blame for. Our policies on how lightly we deal with violent criminals being 
the one that comes to mind for me.
comments.author: Paul Lander

comments.text:
+Paul Lander Your comment sounded pretty apologetic, using the woeful 
"well, not *all* of us are like that" tactic. Maybe I misinterpreted it, 
but that's what it seemed like. The "American and ashamed" attitude is 
pretty trendy nowadays, so I assumed that's where you were coming from.
     Also, I would never claim that there aren't major issues in the 
country; it's just that they're caused by the socialist European bullshit 
that's being brought over here, not by capitalism or anything else 
progressivists like to blame. And if you want someone to blame, I'd start 
with FDR and his lovely New Deal policies - it started there and only got 
worse...
comments.author: Christian Ponicki

comments.text:
+Christian Ponicki I'm not ashamed to be American. As someone who comes 
from a long line of U.S. military folk, I have great pride in the freedoms 
we have in this country. What I don't have time for, is people pretending 
that we don't still have issues that need to be addressed. Do I agree with 
Europe on pretty much any issue regarding their society - not even sort of. 
But I will say the fact that we entertain lawsuits and hand out money 
simply because some retard needs a label to tell them hot coffee can be 
hazardous, doesn't exactly make our country look that intelligent. I have 
more pride in being an American than most, but even I have to admit, there 
are way too many people in this country that aren't worth the dirt our 
ancestors walked on.
comments.author: Paul Lander

comments.text:

I believe companies should be held responsible. Sure, it is just an inch on 
a sub but the company is obviously doing this on purpose. 8% savings per 
sub over millions of subs is a large amount of money saved. Most customers 
will not measure their sandwich to make sure it is as advertised so they 
are oblivious. It reminds me of how cell phone companies advertise 
unlimited data plans then in the fine print buried among thousands of lines 
of legal bullcrap it says it's actually limited to anywhere from 1GB to 5GB 
a month. Sorry but if you say something is unlimited, your customers should 
be able to use it till they are content without any slowdowns, extra 
charges, or complaints from you. If a customer buys a sandwich that is 
advertised as 12 inches or a foot, it should actually be 12 inches or a 
foot. How would you feel if you purchased a "blue t-shirt" from a company 
and they sent you a "green t-shirt"? You wouldn't be happy. Now imagine 
they had no blue t-shirts and only had green t-shirts and kept selling 
these green t-shirts as blue. Any sane person would see this is wrong and 
misleading. In modern society, the only way to get a company to change 
their misleading ways is to sue their asses off in court and win. Some 
companies even factor into their finances a certain amount for lawsuits as 
they expect them. So long as lawsuits don't exceed their factored in 
amount, they remain in profit and their misleading advertisements were 
"worth it" to them. I'm reminded about a bakers dozen.

The whole footlongs not being a foot long case will go nowhere. It doesn't 
matter whether or not the sandwich is actually a foot long, a "footlong" is 
just what the sandwich is called. Also, you paying for the food counts as 
you accepting the food as presented. The only time you would have a legal 
case is if the sandwich contained something incorrect that was not visible 
when the sandwich was presented to you. When you pay for the food, you are 
legally verifying that you agree that the food is to your satisfaction 
based on a visual inspection. That includes the portion size. ﻿

comments.text:
+Daniel Gardiner I still don't see how it's a rip-off.

Most of the cost of your sub goes to the meat thats on it. Given that 
portion sizes are predetermined, it doesn't matter whether your sub is 11" 
or 12". The foot-long turkey, for example, will have 6 slices of turkey no 
matter what.

The rest of the cost goes to the bread/vegetables/sauce. 

The bread is all the same weight, so length doesn't matter here either. You 
get the same amount of bread whether its 11" or 12".

The quantity of vegetables on your sandwich depends on how much you ask 
for. If you think that Subway is trying to cheat you out of that last 1" of 
lettuce, just ask for more. Same goes for quantity of sauce.

To draw a parallel - If a bag of lays chips has 100 chips instead of 120, 
is Frito-Lays ripping their customers off?

On quality control: Quality control isn't an afterthought. Managers (at 
least when I worked at Subway) were fairly strict when it came to 
preparation of bread, sandwiches, etc. That being said, the very nature of 
franchises makes it very hard to check every last detail. Just look at 
McDonalds. Sometimes your Big Macs actually look pretty good. Sometimes 
they're sloppy as hell. That's what happens when you're being served by 16 
year olds who make minimum wage.
comments.author: B. Ribs

comments.text:
Just because it's not a conspiracy doesn't mean people aren't getting 
ripped off, and it was obviously happening often enough to warrant a class 
action suit. If a company is making that much money quality control 
shouldn't be an after thought, especially in the case of a franchise.
comments.author: Daniel Gardiner

comments.text:
+Daniel Gardiner No ones ripping anyone off. The bread arrives at Subway 
stores frozen. If the bread is proofed properly (temp, time, handled 
properly) then the bread is 12" long after baking. if the bread isn't 
proofed properly (most likely scenario is that the employee who is baking 
the bread doesn't give two shits) then the bread might be less than 12" 
long (it probably looks a lot less appealing too.)

This isn't a secret ploy by subway to save money. I mean, it's a franchise 
after all...

captions.text:
• From a loyal TV audience suing because
the weather wasn't right to a severed finger

found in a bowl of chilli, we count 15 of
the strangest cases ever seen in a courtroom

15 - Homeless Man Sues His Parents,
• This one comes in from early last year

when Bernard Bey a homeless man living on
the streets and in jail for over 20 years

sued his parents - to get them a job
• He asked for $200,000 in emotional damages,

to mortgage the parent's home and acquire
two Domino's Pizza restaurants in order to

provide jobs for his entire family
• He quoted his parents as indifferent to

their children's problems, relationships,
poverty, status and station in life - but

that he would drop the case if they would
just sit down and talk to him like a normal

human being
14 - Guy Sues Apple Because His iPad Can Display

Porn,
• A lawyer from Tennessee from accidentally

misspelled Facebook.com and instead wrote
Fuckbook.com, where the images traumatised

him
• He apparently could no longer tell the

difference between internet porn and real
life sex because of the dangerous content

he accessed on an Apple device - and now he
wants to have sex with girls younger than

his wife who he claims to be old
• He suggests that Apple should implement

a type of safe mode for devices that blocks
easy-to-access porn from those unprepared

13 - Subway, (IGNORE TITLES FROM HERE)
• Two New Jersey men sued Subway because

their footlong sandwich, typically 12 inches
long, was one inch from being an entire foot

• Their lawyer went on record saying, the
case was about holding companies responsible

for delivering the products they promised
• Since then many people have taken photos

of their sandwich being 1 inch too short,
and there had been talk of a class action

lawsuit in order to bring justice to those
emotionally scarred by this betrayal

12 - Happy Birthday,
• Everyone who has ever celebrated a birthday

with their family knows this song, but not
many people are aware that it's legally owned

by a music group known as Warner/Chappell
• It means every time the song is sung on

TV or in movies, you have to pay a licensing
fee to these guys - but Jennifer Nelson a

documentary filmmaker decided to turn to the
legal system to get the song moved into public

domain
• It turns out that the melody has been

around since the 1800s, used with different
lyrics for a song called "Good Morning To

All" - the case is: if true, that means the
song is long out of copyright

11 - Bubbles,
• A case that started in 2001 when someone

poured detergent into a public fountain and
created a mountain of bubbles

• A passerby Kathy Kelly tripped on the
bubbles and suffered a cut, which later became

infected and worsened her diabetes
• She sued the city and in 2004, the jury

ruled that the city was responsible for 70%
of the injury because nobody had come to clean

up the bubbles, and Kathy 30% because she
was a klutz - they awarded her over a hundred

thousand dollars and encircled the fountain
with railing

10 - Pants,
• 2005, a dry cleaner loses Roy Pearson's

pair of pants, and in return he tries to sue
them for 54 million dollars

• His entire case hinged on the tear-jerking
tiny violin story about how the sign out the

front of their office read "satisfaction guaranteed"
and that he'd been defrauded by their incompetence

• The judge took his story to heart, laughed
a bit, then ordered Roy to pay for the dry

cleaner's legal fees, and also advised him
never to open a case claiming his pants were

worth 50 million times their actual value
again

9 - Weather,
• Weather stations aren't usually accurate

because of how difficult it is to foresee
conditions that change day-to-day

• One woman from Israel got so fed up with
the inaccuracy that she sued one station for

leading her to believe the day would be sunny
when it was wet and miserable

• She cited her dressing light, catching
the flu, missing the work and getting medicated

claiming the whole ordeal had caused her stress
• She sued the station and won a thousand

dollars
8 - Job,

• One 27-year-old woman who passed her bachelor's
degree in info tech was so furious that she

didn't have a job lined up for her as soon
as she finished the course, that she sued

the school
• Not even 3 months after she graduated,

she stepped up to say the career portion of
her education hadn't been sufficient enough

in providing work opportunities for when she
left

• She sued for $70,000 to recoup her tuition
and an extra $2,000 for the stress of job

hunting
7 - Batman,

• The mayor of a Turkish town called Batman,
totally oblivious about a character also named

Batman, to the point that he actually sued
Warner Bros because of the Dark Knight films

• In his case, he demanded they agree there
to be only one Batman in the world - his town,

that he should receive royalties for use of
the Batman name

• He cited a number of suicide cases in
the town of Batman as psychological trauma

felt by residents - yes, the reason they killed
themselves is due to the shame of Batman getting

his own film and the town ignored
• I'm sure that wouldn't piss off their

families
6 - Field Trip,

• A father annoyed at his daughter decided
the punishment was to ground her from a field

trip she wanted to go on - simple, right?
Except this 12-year-old girl decided to take

her father to court instead
• Since her parents were divorced, they

allowed an objective third party to step in
and rule in the girl's favour - her mother

had already punished her, rendering the father's
attempt to stop her from attending the field

trip redundant
• Safe to say that girl will grow up not

taking crap from a single person on Earth,
especially from the people who raised her

5 - Finger,
• 2005, a woman called Anna tried to sue

a Wendy's restaurant because she found a severed
fingertip in her bowl of chili

• The resulting publicity lost Wendy's a
huge amount from lost sales exceeding 20 million

dollars, but no authorities could figure out
where the finger had come from

• Eventually it was revealed a contact of
Anna's had lost the top of their finger in

a work accident, and Anna had acquired it
to settle a hundred dollar bet - she then

decided to frame Wendy's in the hope of getting
some money

• She ended up getting a four years probation
4 - Taser,

• A double-pronged case stemming from one
incident, a man who was acting crazy while

getting arrested, so the officer drew her
taser and fired but - oh noes - she accidentally

drew her gun and shot him to death
• The city sued the taser company because

of how similar they'd designed their weapon
to a gun, and the man's family sued the city

for, well, shooting the dude in the chest
for no reason

• Despite the officer's attempt to use non-lethal
force, courtrooms still frowned upon their

excessive force against some handcuffed - breaking
the fourth amendment

3 - Johnny Depp,
• Johnny Depp once had a crazy stalker,

a girl in love with him under the illusion
they were dating when, in reality, they weren't

• She went driving one day and got into
an accident, killing another driver - in court,

her lawyer thought it might strengthen her
case to get Johnny Depp to come down and tell

the jury he had no idea who she was - that
she was more than likely insane

• They wanted Johnny Depp to testify against
a relationship he had no idea he was involved

in, to prove a woman was insane - pretty typical
weekend in Hollywood

2 - Cookies,
• Two teenage girls that had the audacity

to go knocking on their neighbours door with
a plate of homemade cookies

• The middle-aged woman who lived there
broke into an anxiety attack upon hearing

the knocks, and so did what any sane human
being would do - she sued the teenage girls

• Even though they apologised, and offered
to pay for her medical bills, the woman still

took them to court asking for $900 - and for
some reason, she won, teaching the kids a

valuable lesson about never helping anyone
because they'll turn around and sue you

1 - Michael Jordan
• One guy who happened to look like Michael

Jordan got so fed up with people stopping
him in the street to ask for his autograph

that he decided to sue Michael's promotional
agent

• For 15 years worth of trauma and personal
injury, this Michael look-a-like asked for

the grand total of $832 million dollars
• When asked why he decided on such a ludicrously

high amount, he responded, I just took my
age multiplied it by seven and two and then

times it by a million - because I guess that's
what I deserve
• Suffice to say, he didn't get diddly squat
